data.text: Contents

Process for reporting babies readmitted to the hospital in the first 28 days of life for feeding problems ............................................................................................................... 17
Introduction

This Policy is based on the UNICEF Baby Friendly Initiative (BFI) standards which are recognised as the standard for best practice in promoting, supporting and sustaining breastfeeding and early infant relationships.
This policy is also supported by the NICE guideline Postnatal Care (2021) which sets out how professionals should support women with Infant Feeding and relationship building.
Scope

The purpose of this policy is to ensure that all Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (‘the Trust') staff understand their role and responsibilities in supporting expectant, new mothers and their partners to feed and care for their baby in ways which support optimal health, development and well-being.

Breastfeeding is an important Public Health measure. There is increasing evidence to demonstrate that breast feeding provides short term and long term benefits to both mother and infant. Breastfeeding offers complete nutrition, comfort and love for the development of healthy infants; human breast milk has been shown to play an important role in the prevention of conditions such as gastroenteritis, respiratory infections, ear infections, allergies, obesity and juvenile onset insulin dependent diabetes mellitus. Mothers who breastfeed have a reduced risk of developing breast and ovarian cancer and osteoporosis.
The Trust promotes breast feeding as the healthiest way for a mother to feed her baby and recognises the important health benefits known to exist for both the mother and child.

All mothers have the right to receive clear and impartial information to enable them to make a fully informed choice as to how they feed and care for their babies. Health care staff will not discriminate against any woman in her chosen method of feeding and will fully support her with her choice.

It is essential that all parents receive clear, concise and impartial information at appropriate times throughout the antenatal, intrapartum and postnatal periods to allow them to make informed choices.

There will be no discrimination against any parent in their chosen method of infant feeding and full support will be given to parents regardless of their chosen feeding method. This policy is designed to reflect best practice in infant feeding, not to dictate the choice of parents.
Maternity services will work together across disciplines and organisations to improve mothers' / parents' experiences of care.

The policy aims for provision of a supportive environment that develops a breastfeeding culture. Within this culture women are more likely to breastfeed exclusively for six months and to continue as part of the infant's diet for at least the first year.
In accordance with professional judgement and codes of practice, clear reasons for deviation from the policy must be written in the mother's and or baby's healthcare records. (NMC 2018)
The Trust will adhere to the International Code for the Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes. .
Outcomes
2.11.1 This policy aims to ensure that the care provided improves outcomes for children and families, specifically to deliver:
An increase in breastfeeding initiation rates.
An increase in breastfeeding rates at 10 days.
Amongst mothers who choose to formula feed, an increase in those doing so as safely as possible, in line with nationally agreed guidance.
Improvements in parents' experiences of care.
A reduction in the number of avoidable re-admissions for feeding problems.
Achievement of UNICEF's Baby Friendly Initiative Accreditation.
Definitions

table_items.text: The infant has received only breastmilk from his/her mother or a wet nurse, or expressed breastmilk (EBM), and no other liquids or solids, with the exception of drops of syrups consisting of vitamins, mineral supplements or medicines.
Partial breastfeeding refers to a situation where the baby is receiving some breastfeeds but is also being given other food or food-based fluids, such as formula milk of weaning foods.
A pattern of feeding when the baby is fed at prescribed intervals due to illness or prematurity
A feeding relationship which is sensitive, reciprocal and about more than nutrition
A baby is held naked next to its mother's skin, regulating breathing, heart rate and temperature, providing relaxation and calm for mother and baby. If the mother is unable or
reluctant, her partner may experience skin contact.
A method of providing supplementary feeds of either breastmilk or formula to a breastfed baby without using teats or bottles
The woman and her baby are kept together 24 hours a day regardless of the method of feeding.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Clinical Director, Clinical Lead for Obstetrics and Gynaecology and Consultant Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

The Clinical Director for the Division of Women and Children along with the Clinical Lead for Obstetrics and Gynaecology and the Consultant Obstetrician and Gynaecologists must ensure that all clinical staff are aware of the guideline for Infant Feeding. They are responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the Women's Health CSU.
Chief Executive:

The Chief Executive as the Accounting Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. He/she will delegate the full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.
Medical Director:
The Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems,

processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all medical and dental staff are able to comply with the  contents of this document. In addition, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the
monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the
appropriate forum as indicated in the document.
Director of Nursing:

The Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non-medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Director of Operations:
The Director of Operations is responsible for ensuring that there are systems and processes in place to communicate and implement this document in the clinical areas.
Divisional Clinical Directors:

The Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate. In addition, the Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff comply with the contents of the document.
Divisional General Managers

The Divisional General Managers are responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Head of Midwifery and Gynaecology, Matrons, Ward Managers, Midwifery Sisters and Senior Nurses

The Head of Midwifery and Gynaecology is responsible, along with the Matrons, Ward Managers, Midwifery Sisters and Senior Nurses for the implementation of this guideline within the Women's Health CSU.
Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads/ Unit Managers:

Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads and Unit Managers are responsible for implementing this document in the Clinical Service Unit and for monitoring the impact on the service and reporting compliance with the document. They are accountable to the Divisional Clinical Director and General Manager in this respect.
Lead Nurses:

Lead Nurses are responsible for ensuring that all nursing staff (including Nurse Specialists, Practitioners/Advisors) within the Clinical Service Unit comply with the contents of this document and for taking action when this is not the case. The Lead Nurse will make sure that all necessary training is provided.
Medical Staff
The Consultant holds ultimate responsibility for ensuring that all members of the medical team follow this document.
Senior Sisters/Nursing Staff

The Senior Sister/nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward comply with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is the case.
All Staff
All staff, including ancillary staff, that have had specific training are required to follow this policy to avoid conflicting advice and must have clear reasons where this is not possible.
Compliance with WHO code
Compliance to the International Code of Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes will be adhered to (WHO).
There should be no direct contact between baby milk company personnel, mothers and professionals. Contact should only be through the Specialist Midwife for Infant Feeding.
Routine collection of data will be carried out at stated times in accordance with Department of Health specifications and UNICEF BFI.
Annual audits will be undertaken to determine compliance.

No advertising of breastmilk substitutes, feeding bottles, teats or dummies is permissible in any part of this Trust. The display of manufacturer's logos on items such as calendars and stationery is also prohibited.
No literature provided by infant formula manufacturers is permitted. Educational material for distribution to women and their families must be approved by the Specialist Midwife Infant Feeding.

Parents who have made a fully informed choice to artificially feed their babies should be shown how to prepare formula feeds correctly, either individually or in small groups, in the postnatal period. No routine group instruction on the preparation of artificial feeds will be given in the antenatal period as evidence suggests that information given at this time is less well retained and may serve to undermine confidence in breastfeeding.
The policy will be implemented in conjunction with the Trusts Infant Feeding guidelines.
Communicating the Infant feeding policy
This policy is to be communicated to all healthcare staff who have any contact with pregnant women and mothers. All staff will have access to a copy of this policy.
All new staff will be orientated to the policy as part of their induction programme.
The full version of the policy should be available in each ward area on request.
The policy will be audited once a year (see section on Monitoring and Auditing)
The policy will be reviewed every two years.
Pregnancy

All pregnant women will have the opportunity to discuss feeding and caring for their baby with a health professional (or other suitably trained designated person). This discussion will include the following topics:
The value of connecting with their growing baby in utero
The value of skin contact for all mothers and babies
The importance of responding to their baby's needs for comfort, closeness and feeding after birth, and the role that keeping their baby close has in supporting this.
Feeding, including:
All staff are required to follow the UNICEF Baby Friendly Standards as detailed in this document and document their care in the antenatal notes.

No group instruction on the preparation of powdered formula feeds will be given in the antenatal period as evidence suggests that information given at this time is less well retained and may serve to undermine confidence in breastfeeding.
Parent education classes should underpin the information given by Midwives as part of their one-to-one discussion. Local outlines will ensure all staff are aware of the content required.
Birth

All mothers will be offered the opportunity to have uninterrupted skin to skin contact with their baby at least until after the first feed and for as long as they want, so that the instinctive behaviour of breast seeking (baby) and nurturing (mother) is given an opportunity to emerge
Skin-to-skin contact should never be interrupted at staff's instigation to carry out routine procedures

All mothers will be encouraged to offer the first breastfeed in skin contact when the baby shows signs of readiness to feed. The aim is not to rush the baby to the breast but to be sensitive to the baby's instinctive process towards self-attachment.
When mothers choose to formula feed, they will be encouraged to offer the first feed in skin contact.
Those mothers who are unable (or do not wish) to have skin contact immediately after birth, will be encouraged to commence skin contact as soon as they are able, or so wish.
Mothers with a baby on the neonatal unit are:
Enabled to start expressing milk as soon as possible after birth (within 2-4 hours)
Supported to express effectively
It is the joint responsibility of midwifery and neonatal staff to ensure that mothers who are separated from their baby receive this information and support
Safety considerations

Vigilance as to the baby's well-being is a fundamental part of postnatal care in the first few hours after birth. For this reason, normal observations of the baby's temperature, breathing, colour and tone should continue throughout the period of skin contact, in the same as would occur if the baby were in a cot (this includes calculation of the Apgar score at 1, 5 and 10 minutes following birth). Observations should also be make of the mother, with prompt removal of the baby if the health of either gives rise to concern.

Staff should have a conversation with the mother and her companion about the importance of recognising changes in the baby's colour or tone and the need to alert staff immediately if they are concerned.

It is important to ensure that the baby cannot fall on the floor or become trapped in bedding or by the mother's body. Parents and staff should be reminded that cot sides are for transportation only and should not be used when in a bay. Particular care should be taken with the position of the baby, ensuring the head is supported so the infant's airway does not become obstructed.
Notes – mothers

Observations of the mother's vital signs and level of consciousness should be continued throughout the period of skin-to-skin contact. Mothers may be very tired following birth, and so may need constant support and supervision to observe changes in their baby's condition or to reposition their baby when needed.

Many mothers can continue to hold their baby in skin to skin contact during perineal suturing, providing they have adequate pain relief. However, a mother who is in pain may not be able to hold her baby safely. Babies should not be in skin to skin contact with their mothers when they are receiving Entonox or other analgesics that impact consciousness.
Where mothers choose to give a first feed of formula milk in skin contact, particular care should be taken to ensure the baby is kept warm.
Notes – babies
All babies should be routinely monitored whilst in skin-to-skin contact with mother or father. Observation to include:
Checking that the baby's position is such that a clear airway is maintained: Observe respiratory rate and chest movement and listen for unusual breathing sounds or absence of noise from the baby.
Colour: The baby should be assessed by looking at the whole of the baby's body, as the limbs can often be discoloured first. Subtle changes to colour indicate changes in the baby's condition.
Tone: The baby should have a good tone and not be limp or unresponsive.
Temperature: Ensure the baby is kept warm during skin contact.
Always listen to parents and respond immediately to any concerns raised.
Supporting women to breastfeed and how to maintain lactation

Encouragement will be given in the extended use of skin-to-skin contact after the initial post-delivery experience. All mothers will be encouraged to enjoy this experience at any time uninterrupted by any routine procedural interference.
Mothers should be offered further help with breastfeeding within six hours of delivery. A Health Professional should be available to assist a mother with all breastfeeds during her hospital stay.
A skilled practitioner will teach all breastfeeding mothers how to hand express. Written communication in an appropriate format will be used where necessary to assist mothers understanding.

Mothers will have the opportunity to discuss breastfeeding in the first few hours after birth as appropriate to their own needs and those of their baby. This discussion will include information on responsive feeding and feeding cues.
Mothers should experience a seamless service between skilled practitioners
providing continuity of information and support, with all staff having the skills to be able to assist on positioning and attachment. They should be able to explain the
necessary techniques to a mother thereby helping her to acquire this skill for
herself. Written communication will be used where necessary to assist mothers
understanding.
Prior to transfer home, all breastfeeding mothers will receive information, both verbally and in writing, about how to recognise effective feeding to include:
The signs which indicate that their baby is receiving sufficient milk and what to do if they suspect this is not the case;
How to recognise signs that breastfeeding is not progressing normally (e.g. sore nipples, breast inflammation).
All mothers leaving hospital should be provided with sources of professional local/National and voluntary breastfeeding support.
Breastfeeding support groups and hospital/community staff are encouraged to liaise in order to provide ongoing support for mothers.
Raising awareness of the local communities is seen as an integral part of the
promotion of breastfeeding. Voluntary groups, as part of the community will be
used to help reach this goal. This will include participating with professionals in the development of policies and in school programmes and raising the profile with local businesses.

A formal feeding assessment will be carried out using modified UNICEF Baby Friendly assessment tool as often as required in the first week with a minimum of two assessments taking place in the first ten days, to ensure effective feeding and the well-being of mother and baby. This assessment will include a
dialogue/discussion with the mother to reinforce what is going well and where necessary develop an appropriate plan of care to address any issues that have been identified.

When a mother and her baby are separated for medical reasons, it is the responsibility of all health professionals caring for both mother and baby to ensure that the mother is given help and encouragement to express her milk and maintain her lactation during periods of separation.

Mothers who are separated from their babies should be enabled to start expressing within 2-4 hours of birth, unless they are clinically unstable / unwell enough to do so as early initiation has long term benefits for milk production

Mothers who are separated from their babies should be encouraged to express milk at least eight times in a  hour period, including at least once in the night (with an optimal 10-12 expressions offering the best long term yield). They should be shown how to express breastmilk both by hand and by pump.
Professionals must continue to record and where appropriate observe the progress of breastfeeding at each contact. This will enable information to be given to prevent or remedy early problems.

For those mothers who require additional support for more complex breastfeeding challenges, a referral to the specialist service should be made, along with details of the Facebook and Twitter sites run by the Specialist Midwives for Infant Feeding (Basildon only)

The Specialist Midwives for Infant Feeding are Lisette Harris contact details are; email lisette.harris@nhs.net or telephone 01268 524900 or 07385930486 at Basildon, Victoria Hopley victoria.hopley@nhs.net  01702 435555 extension 7296 at Southend and Charlotte Lowden  mse.infantfeeding@nhs.net  at Broomfield 01245 513676
Responsive feeding
The term responsive feeding is used to describe a feeding relationship which is sensitive, reciprocal and about more than nutrition.
Staff should ensure that mothers have the opportunity to discuss this aspect of

feeding and reassure mothers that: breastfeeding can be used to feed, comfort and calm babies; breastfeeds can be long or short, breastfed babies cannot be overfed or ‘spoiled' by too much feeding and breastfeeding will not tire mother any more
than caring for a new baby without breastfeeding.
Find out more in UNICEF UK's responsive feeding info sheet: unicef.uk/bf- responsive
Supporting the exclusive use of breastmilk

Mothers who breastfeed will be provided with information about why exclusive breastfeeding leads to the best outcomes for their baby and why it is particularly important during the establishment of breastfeeding.
When exclusive breastfeeding is not possible, the value of continuing partial breastfeeding will be emphasised and mothers will be supported to maximise the amount of breastmilk their baby receives.

Mothers who give other feeds in conjunction with breastfeeding will be enabled to do so as safely as possible and with the least possible disruption to breastfeeding. This will include appropriate information and a discussion regarding the potential impact of introducing a teat when a baby is learning to breastfeed.
A full record will be made of all supplements given, including the rationale for supplementation and the discussion held with parents.
Supplementation rates will be audited by continuous audit supported by monthly sampling/record reviews. See Infant Feeding Hospital and Community Guideline.
All breastfeeding mothers returning to work should be given information which will support them to continue breastfeeding and maintain lactation at this time.
Modified feeding regimes
There are a number of clinical indications for a short-term modified feeding
regime in the early days after birth. Examples include preterm or small for
gestational age babies and those who are excessively sleepy after birth. Frequent feeding, including a minimum number of feeds in 24 hours, should be offered to
ensure safety.
Early postnatal period: support for parenting and close
relationships
Skin-to-skin contact will be encouraged throughout the postnatal period.

All parents will be supported to understand a newborn baby's needs, including encouraging frequent touch and sensitive verbal/visual communication, keeping babies close, responsive feeding and safe sleeping practice.
Mothers who bottle feed will be encouraged to hold their baby close during feeds and offer the majority of feeds to their baby themselves to help enhance the mother- baby relationship.
Parents will be given information about local parenting support that is available.
Use of Artificial Teats, Dummies and Nipple Shields

The use of dummies or artificial teats and nipples shields during the establishment of breastfeeding interferes with the stimulation of the milk supply and may disrupt the baby's oral motor co-ordination.
Where supplementation has been prescribed for a breastfed baby it should be given by cup/syringe and a full record be made in the appropriate notes.
Nipple shields reduce stimulation of the milk supply and may lead to rejection of the breast by the baby.
Some parents may choose to use artificial teat, dummies and nipple shields and
whilst it is their right to choose, it is the responsibility of the health care professional to give accurate information about the disadvantages and detrimental effects
dummies can have on the establishment of breastfeeding and the long-term
consequences for responsive feeding and milk supply should be discussed fully
with the parents.
Whenever a nipple shield is used a skilled practitioner should give every help to the mother to discontinue its use as soon as possible.
Care for mothers who have chosen to feed their newborn with
powdered infant formula

All formula milks available in the UK have to be of a similar composition to comply with EU compositional requirements this ensures that they are all nutritionally adequate for infants. No brand or type of formula is closer to breastmilk than any other. The International Code of Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes requires that as a health care professional you should not recommend any particular brand.

Mothers should be aware that they should use first milks only for the first year then move on to full fat cows milk. Parents should be advised that it is unnecessary to change to a Follow on milk at 6 months.

There are different types of formula milk available such as hungry baby or comfort milk. There is no evidence that any of these milks have any benefit. If parents wish to use any milk other than first milk this should be discussed and evidence-based information provided to enable an informed choice. Parents can be directed to https://www.firststepsnutrition.org/

Staff should ensure that all mothers who have chosen to feed their newborn with powdered infant formula are able to correctly sterilise equipment and make up a bottle of infant formula during the early postnatal period and before discharge from hospital. NB In Broomfield women are asked to bring in prepared formula as there are not the facilities for preparation of powdered formula milk.
Mothers who formula feed will be enabled to do so as safely as possible through the offer of a demonstration and / or discussion about how to prepare infant formula.
Mothers who formula feed will have a discussion about the importance of responsive feeding and be encouraged to:
Respond to cues that their baby is hungry
Invite their baby to draw in the teat rather than forcing the teat into their baby's mouth
Pace the feed so that their baby is not forced to feed more than they want to
Recognise their baby's cues that they have had enough milk and avoid forcing their baby to take more milk than baby wants.
Community midwives will check and reinforce learning following the mothers transfer home.
All information given should follow guidance from the Department of Health and should be reinforced with written information.
Mothers should be given contact details of health professional support available for feeding issues once they have left hospital.
Process for reporting babies readmitted to the hospital in the first
28 days of life for feeding problems.

When a community midwife or other health professional identifies a problem that may be related to feeding in the first 28 days of life i.e. weight loss or jaundice, they should telephone, the Paediatric Assessment Unit for assessment. If and when the baby is admitted to the Children's Ward, then the Specialist Midwives for Infant Feeding should also be notified by email, so as to provide support and information.
At Broomfield, babies will be referred to the Paediatric Registrar and if accepted they will be seen on, and admitted as necessary, onto the Postnatal ward.
Training requirements
The Trust is committed to provide training for all staff that has contact with pregnant women, mothers and their families.
The Clinical Tutor for Obstetrics and the Specialist Midwives – Infant Feeding, in association with all Midwifery Managers, will determine if training, regarding the
protocol, is required and actioned accordingly. The Practice Development Midwife will ensure that training records are maintained regarding this.
New staff will receive training within six months of their appointment.
All staff have the primary responsibility to support breastfeeding and will   receive a level of training appropriate to their professional group.
The Specialist Midwives – Infant Feeding will be responsible for ensuring that all staff are given the relevant training in respect of breastfeeding – this will include the two
day introduction with ongoing yearly updates.
Professional and support staff will receive training in the skills needed to
assist mothers who have chosen to formula feed including the reconstitution of powdered infant formula and sterilisation techniques, at a level
appropriate to their role and responsibilities within maternity.
All clerical and ancillary staff will be orientated to the policy and receive training to enable them to refer breastfeeding queries appropriately.
The training programme will be supported by a curriculum incorporating the UNICEF UK Baby Friendly Standards for Maternity Services.
In order to provide a consistent programme of education for any facilitator to use, a written document is available which outlines the content and details the outcomes of the training.

Parents' experiences of care will be listened to through regular audit, parents' experience surveys (e.g. Care Quality Commission survey of women's experiences of maternity services), the appointment of
Peoples Experience and Engagement Lead.
18.11 Paediatric and obstetric medical staff are orientated to the policy and receive training according to their professional needs.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Specialist Midwife Infant Feeding, Maternity Governance Group

data.text: This Infant Feeding Policy will be monitored and audited by the Specialist Midwives - Infant Feeding and the Advanced Specialist Midwife- Audit and Research

Where audit has identified any deficiencies, recommendations and action plans will be developed and changes implemented accordingly. The Specialist Midwife – Audit and Research is responsible for reporting the outcome of audits and progress against action plans to the Women's Health Clinical Governance Group. Changes will be highlighted to all relevant staff through Maternity Matrons and Obstetric Consultants.

An action plan will be developed to address any deficiencies or recommendations made; completion of the action plan will be monitored by the Maternity Governance Group. Any barriers to implementation will be risk assessed and where necessary added to the Women and Children's Risk Register.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Maternity Policy working group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve MSE guidelines and policies guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the relevant staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 2)
References
Implementing the Baby Friendly best practice standards (UNICEF 2001)

The UNICEF UK Baby Friendly Initiative Audit Tool, to monitor breastfeeding support in the maternity services. Appendix A – Writing and evaluating the breastfeeding policy.  www.babyfriendly.org.uk. (Accessed 2014)
National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE). (2021).Postnatal care NICE guideline [NG197]. London: NICE
Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC) (2018) The code: standards of conduct, performance and ethics for nurses and midwives. London: Nursing and Midwifery Council

What are you proposing to change?
Full Review and Merge of 3 site policies to Standardise across the MSE trust.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Who benefits from this change and how?
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
